DOC.HEAD: Bernstein Conducts Concerts in Honor of East European Freedom
DOC.TEXT: Beethoven's Ninth Symphony became an ode to freedom on Saturday as Leonard Bernstein united musicians from East and West at the start of a Christmas musical gala to honor Eastern Europe's struggle for freedom. Hundreds of people dressed in their finest poured into the gleaming Schauspielhaus in East Berlin on Saturday afternoon for a rehearsal before two official concerts of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. Bernstein was invited to perform by Justus Frantz, performance director of West Germany's Bavarian Radio, to celebrate the historic events in East Germany that led to the opening of the country's borders Nov. 9. ``I just couldn't say no,'' Bernstein said as he stepped backstage after the nearly two-hour rehearsal. Young people mobbed the legendary conductor for autographs outside the concert hall before he returned to West Berlin. Bernstein conducted the Ninth Symphony at the first concert Saturday night in the West Berlin Philharmonic. He will conduct a second performance in East Berlin on Christmas morning. Frantz said Beethoven's Ninth Symphony was chosen because of the symbolism of the final movement of the piece, which is based on Friedrich Schiller's Ode to Joy with its plea for world brotherhood. ``Europe is opening up. All men are becoming brothers and so we chose the Ninth Symphony and musicians from all nations as a salute to freedom,'' Frantz told The Associated Press. East Germany officially drops visa requirements for West German travelers on Sunday, and the performance in West Berlin was timed to end as the clock struck midnight. The international orchestra includes musicians from West and East Germany, Great Britain, the Soviet Union, France and the United States, the four victorious World War II allies still technically responsible for governing Berlin. The 71-year-old American conductor is the latest in a series of world-renowned musicians to travel to Berlin since the wall began to crumble on Nov. 9. Sir Yehudi Menuhin conducted a benefit concert in West Berlin this month to help rebuild decaying East German city centers and Mstislav Rostropovich and Daniel Barenboim also played in West Berlin shortly after the concrete barrier was opened.
